com.example.kit.command

Class MacroCommand

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.example.kit.command.Command
      • com.example.kit.command.MacroCommand

  • public class MacroCommand
extends Command
    Command that provides the function of executing multiple commands in sequence.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      MacroCommand()
      Construct a macro command, with an empty list of commands.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addCommand(Command command)
      Add a Command to the macro that will be executed when the macro is executed.
      void execute()
      Execution method of the macro, executing all subcommands sequentially.
      boolean isReversible()
      If any command in the macro is not reversible, the entire macro is not reversible.
      void unexecute()
      Reverses the commands executed in reverse sequential order.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

        Construct a macro command, with an empty list of commands.

    • Method Detail

      • addCommand

        public void addCommand(Command command)
        Add a Command to the macro that will be executed when the macro is executed.
        Parameters:
        command - Command to be added to the macro.

      • execute

        public void execute()
        Execution method of the macro, executing all subcommands sequentially.
        Specified by:
        execute in class Command

      • unexecute

        public void unexecute()
        Reverses the commands executed in reverse sequential order.
        Specified by:
        unexecute in class Command

      • isReversible

        public boolean isReversible()
        If any command in the macro is not reversible, the entire macro is not reversible.
        Overrides:
        isReversible in class Command
        Returns:
        False if any subcommand is permanent, otherwise true.
